lines.text: beware of the furniture movers. When the axe falls, they're usually the first to know. People see them coming and they shit.

[into a phone]
This is Howard Gross, talking! I'm the head of this division. I didn't get this job because I'm a moron... I got this job because IIIIIIIII'm NOT a moron! Listen, my neck is on the line here and I'm the one who's gonna determine if this is brilliant or not brilliant and I'm telling you it's crap! Listen... listen to me for a second! I'm not trying to sell pantyhose! It's on my head! I've got to convince the public that killing 100,000 jobs, and closing down a plant, and moving it into Latin America is not unpatriotic! You understand what that means? I've got to sell this being as patriotic as a goddamned apple pie! If anybody up there sees this, I'm gonna die. They're gonna kill me!
[the intercom buzzes]

I got... I gotta go! The phone is going here! I've got to put you on hold! I got 35 lines going here! I mean I'm 35-years-old, I've got the one line that has three lines coming in and 35 people looking at me! Hang on for a second!

See that down there, Colonel? That construction? That's us. And those two skyscrapers? That's also us. I own all that. When I first came to this city over 30 years ago, I had less then $43 million in my pockets! Now... I'm a multi-billionaire!
[first lines]

Hi. My name is Pete Helmes. 30 years ago I started a small company called INC Bearing and Tool and with these balls of steel I built INC International. Now we produce over 10,000 products, from the 50-megaton nuclear warhead to a creamer and nuttier peanut butter and a new, quieter artificial heart. Every day at INC we're developing new products that will improve your life, like Permalax, an all-new laxative implant, that relieves irregularity for up to 25 years with a one-step implantation. I had the Permalax implant, now I'm regular for life. But more important, we care about you and we care about our employees. INC is the company that cares about people.
[Sal's car is destroyed]
My tape! My Julio Iglesias tape!
the secret to survival here is never make a decision.
Never?
Never. The minute you do, you're screwed.

Since the 1984 oil discovery in New Guinea, we have sold the Bu!kais hill tribesmen 20 of our S-24 fighters. At $21 million per unit, that's $252 million. This has started a local arms race between the Bu!kais, and their local neighbors the Kla!klalas. Now the Kla!klalas also happen to be sitting an a large amount of oil. And now the Kla!klalas want to buy 20 of our new X-24/X-Ray Ultra Pursuit fighters for a total of $480 million.
What are the chances of war between them?
Very good sir. Our spare parts replacement contracts could be very lucrative.
Who trains their flight personnel?
Well, as near as we can assess it... well... they don't actually fly the planes. They sort of roll them down hills... crashing them into each other.
Personally, I think that it's a shameful waste of incredible kill power.
Make the deal.
Absolutely.

Mr. Chairman, we are a company on the move. I have two mega stocks and a super promotional idea that can bring INC from $500 million, to $1 billion in gross revenue. That is not about white power, nor is it about black power. It's about green power! Money! M-O-N-E-Y! We're talking about geometric progression. One... four... eight... 16... the numbers boggle the mind! So in conclusion, all we have to do is to get off the dime, and put this show on the road. Thank you very much.
Exactly what is our side of the Allenville story?
Were losing money hand over fist.
That's not true.
there are no truths, only stories.
Don't you think it's strange, Max? They keep promoting me. I don't do anything!
Hey, did you know that the Japanese are working on some kind of micro orgasm. Soon, you'll be able to have group sex on a silicon chip no bigger than my fingernail.
Max! You're not taking me seriously! This place is totally bananas! Any normal person would have quit a long time ago.
Relax, what are you worried about? Helmes has his eye on you. You're in line for another big promotion.
Yeah, as soon as somebody drops dead, or jumps, or maybe I'm supposed to pull the trigger myself. There're really doing it up there, Max. They're rigging things up. For what?
when the tough get going, the weak get screwed.
I can't play it like that.
It's the only way to play it Jack.
What about you? You're not like the rest of them. How do you survive it?

I just go with the flow. I flipped out years ago. I only look sane, but I'm not. The secret is you have to be crazy to maintain your sanity up here. But you're sane, Jack. That's why you're going crazy.
In the old days, I'd have had that son of a bitch in cement and dumped into the river before you can say Henry Ford!
Unfortunately, these are the post-Watergate 1980s.
Well, then shoot him!
Not a wise idea, sir.
I'm one of the most powerful men in this world, and if I can't have someone shot, then what the hell does it mean to have power anymore?
Well, you are just screwing your way to the top, aren't you?
I wouldn't be much of an executive if I screwed my way to the bottom. Would I?
I'm an optimist, Colonel. I look down there and see if there's anything else for me to buy.
[at a bar]
Max, I came as soon as you called. What happened?

[refering to Rabinovich]
They fired him this morning.

[drunk]
I'll kill myself! My whole life, my career, my future was at INC. I know, I'll shoot my brains out. Make it easier. No problem for anybody just... bang!

Apparently, a letter with his card enclosed was dropped off yesterday afternoon at the office of a major Saudi oil company that we do a lot of business with. It said that INC wouldn't boycott the Israelis and that the Saudis could go screw themselves.
What?
Well, the shiek freaked out and Dantley had to kiss a whole lot of Saudi ass to cool him off and they insisted that Rabinovich be fired.
Who the hell would have put Rabinovich's card...
That's no longer an issue, Jack. Don't get involved with something that doesn't concern you if you want to survive here at INC.
You're related to Senator Issel, is that right? Am I correct?

[watching it on the TV]
No.
Yes, I am.
Son of a bitch!
I'm his son.
Lying goddamn bastard!
Don't fall for it, Jack.
Fall for what?

For the lie we keep telling ourselves. We do the dirty stuff to get the power. It'll give us all the good things we really want. Then we get the power, we can't even remember what goddamn thing what it was we wanted it for in the first place.
[watching Helmes helicopter above]
There goes Helmes now. I'm fired! I'm gone, I'm finished!
Al, you're imagining things.
At Friday's meeting with Helmes, he didn't make eye contact with me once. It's a sign, I'm fucking dead in this company!
You're crazy!
Crazy?
No, paranoid!
Paranoid? You got your goddamn bag of pecans this week from Helmes, I didn't get any bag of...
But what does that have to do with...
I'm dead in this company!

[on the phone]
Look, what are you people trying to do to me? I have a $75,000 Mercedes Benz in the shop that's leaking more oil than Poland! I've got a dead father-in-law who's pissed off that he can't have a semi-plot to be buried in, and I've got a cat in the hospital at $100 a day - I could put him up at the Hyatt for 75. You guys are killing me up here! I'm dying! I'm dying!
[hangs up the phone as he begins have a major heart attack]
I love this business!

[throws a large piece of meat on Jack's desk]
Do you know what this is, Mr. Issel?
Is this a trick question?
Okay now, what do you say Jack?
I say that you two guys, are two of the biggest assholes I've ever met.
You're way out of line, Mister Issel!
Jack, this is a very complicated foreign policy issue at stake here!

Don't give me this "foreign policy" stuff. I call it contemptible horse shit... sir! You just want to buy yourselves a country as if it was a stolen TV set. Then you launder hot goods and dirty dealings through something you call "foreign policy." My God. America's a democracy. We're not some international fried chicken chain!
We have a very *nasty* terrorist problem in San Marcos, don't we, Senator?
Mm-hmm.
If the army had the guns, we just might be able to stop the killing.
It's a bitch of a problem, isn't it, Jack?
Well, actually, I've been reading that it's the *army* that's doing most of the killing.
Ha.
Jack, the army has been busting its ass to eliminate the murder and the torture and the human rights violations down there.
Left-wing terrorists fire-bombed our 26th Mr. Chicken franchise just yesterday.
The Marxists are denying the people of Latin America their right to eat Mr. Chicken. And, they're denying Mr. Chicken his human right to franchise and make a profit.
Well, I sure as hell don't want some made-in-Moscow Mr. Cabbage Roll shoved down my throat against my will.
Absolutely. Those peasants deserve the dignity and human right to eat Mr. Chicken when and where they please.

And Jack, when that right is threatened in the Western Hemisphere, it becomes a national security issue for the United States of America. We're talking of the very survival of the entire concept of internationally franchised chicken, Jack! You've got work to do.
[Jack and Max's limo is surrounded by hundreds of angry protesters]
This is death! Let's get the hell out of here.
[Jack opens the limo door and gets out]
Jack, what are you doing?
Max, this is a great opportunity for us! There's TV news cameras out there.
Jack, get back in the car. Get back in the car!
[Jack walks off into the crowd]

[to Sal]
Sal, I'm going out there. Keep the motor running.
I'm not going to do that, sir. The motor could heat up or...

[interrupting]
Sal, do me a favor.
What's that, sir?
Don't call me "sir". These people are gonna think I'm in charge here. Call me Max.
Max. Sure, no problem... Max.

[into a phone]
Mr. Yonge's on line three. He's just seen the campaign. He sounds upset.

[into the phone]
Tell him to hold!
Mr. Raybeck is on four. He's also seen the campaign. He also sounds upset.
Tell Raybeck to hold!
Your wife's on five from the hospital. Her father just passed away.
Tell my wife to hold!
Your mechanic's on six. He wants to talk to you abour your Mercedes. That's all.

[calms down]
Put my mechanic on.
[clicks switch and begins talking in a calm and happy tone]
Hey. How are you doing, Lars?

[voice]
Hello, Mr. Gross. How are you? Good talking to you.

[into the phone]
I'm fine. No, I'm great. You guys are great. So, is my car gonna be ready for me to pick up this afternoon or what?

[voice]
No, we're having a problem with your car. It's more then just an oil leak. I'm afraid will have to fix the whole transmission. I'm talking a price of $2,500, I'd say.
Twenty-five-hundred? What are you talking about? I just brought it in this morning for an oil change. Just oil.

[voice]
Plus labor and parts, we're talking a price of over $4,000.

[suddenly angry again; talking fast]
Wait, wait, wait! You wanna come over and see my driveway? I got no oil on my driveway! What are you talking about a leak? You guys know anything? You guys are a bunch of goniffs! You bring in a car, you put a leak in it so you can charge me thousands! It's under warranty! You guys are goniffs! You guys are worse then thieves! You guys think you have a monopoly because you have a goddamn dealership there? You're crazy! I bring in 15 at 25, at 35, for a goddamn oil change! That's under warranty, that transmission! I work in here all day long! I'm 35 years old! I'm the head of this division! I'm gonna have a goddamn heart attack trying to pay for this car!

[into the phone as a medic is trying to recessitate the dead Gross]
I'm sorry Mr. Gross isn't available.

[voice]
Well, where is he?
Well, I wouldn't tell what Mr. Gross is doing right now. He's... being busy.

[to Gross' Secretary]
He's dead.

[into the phone]
He's dead.

[exits]
I'll call the coronor.

[voice]
Well, let's make it after lunch.
After lunch is just as bad. Mr. Gross is dead. He'll still be dead after lunch.

[voice]
Look, Mr. Yonge is a very busy man. He gets very upset...
Yes, I know Mr. Yonge gets upset when we cancel business meetings, but I regret to inform you that Mr. Gross has passed away.

[voice]
Passed away? You mean you're not joking? He's really dead?
No longer alive, correct.

[voice]
Try aspirin or if he's having a heart attack...

The man is dead! He's turning green as we speak. Mr. Gross is not going to make it to lunch and he's not going to make it to the meeting. So if Mr. Yonge wants to see Mr. Gross that badly, I'll ship Mrs. Gross' body down there by internal mail!

[after seeing Steadman commit suicide]
Two in one morning.
Welcome to the world of big business, Jack.

Women rise so much in this compay. But I intend on going to the top. As Mr. Gross' replacement as head of public relations, you will work for me now and report all work to me. By the way, I wanted to inform you that you've been promoted to executive vice president of external relations.
But this is just my first week.
Then you must have good friends upstairs. But don't give your hopes up. It's basically the same job you had in the complaints department but with 10% more salary and 90% more responsibility.
[takes the papers that Jack has]
Is this for me?
It's just a complaint.

[reading the complaint]
What is the Allenville 25,000?
That's the population of a small town upstate that's fighting to have their textile plant stay open. We're closing the plant at the end of this week and all employees will be layed off.
So?
So I was thinking if we can find a way to keep the plant open and find some securities for the workers.
Very good. Write up a report.
Write up a report?
Mr. Dantley appreciates all the necessary information before he makes a major decision. Information is power, Jack.
I agree. Absolutely.
[Jane walks back to her desk where she sits down and begins applying makeup and stares seductivly at Jack]
Did you want something else?
Uh... no ma'am!
[Jack exits]

[into a phone]
Sid? Frank Steadman here! I'm dead! I'm finnished! Heath Swary wouldn't have announced this move until Christmas! It's the headline in the goddamned Wall Street Journal! The SEC is gonna want to know why I sold 50,000 Allenville shares the day before we torpeded the plant! I could go to jail! What... no I can't hold! Don't put me on hold! Sid? Sid? Crap!
[hangs up the phone]
Sal, would you get this thing moving?
We're stuck in a traffic jam, sir. I'm not the great Houdini.
Well, blow your horn like everyone else!
Only a fool blows his horn in a traffic jam, sir.
[Steadman leans forward and begins pressing on the steering wheel horn]
[Steaman arrives at his office to find furniture movers moving out all his furniture]
Hey! What the hell are you doing? Put it down! Down!
Hey, all I know is what is on the work order.
Why are you doing this? Who told you to do this to me?
Someone said that the guy in here just died.
Died? Do I look dead? What the hell do you mean "died"?
[grabbs Jack standing nearby]
Do I look dead?
Uh... not to me, sir.
This is Jack Issel. He's starting here today...
Out of my frickin' way!
What do you think, Jack?
It's perfect.
Perfect. That's perfect... this is perfect.
[She exhales cigarette smoke]
I'm perfect.
You never, NEVER hold your glasses together with a piece of tape and a paper clip, Mister Reubenstein!
It's Rabinovich.
We have other executives but we hope you're behind us, Jane.
Absolutely, 100%!
We need to stand together as women!
Of course! As a woman 120%!
Jack Issel? Scott Dantley, chief executive officer of INC. Welcome aboard.
Thank you, sir. It's good to be here.
Bob Nixon, chief financial officer. My pleasure.

[to Jack]
I know your father. Great senator, great American, outstanding human being.

Well, he's managed to stay out of jail despite the bribery, corruption, tax evasion, solicitation, and domestic abuse charges that have been brought against him. At least me and my Mom are proud of him for that, sir.
Do you think you have what it takes up here?
You mean can I play hardball?
No, I mean can you kiss ass?
[Jack and Max enter Gross' office unaware that he is dead]
Gross screams a lot. He's a little nuts, but you'll get used to him.
Right.
Don't worry. You can live with him as long as you lift your end of the load.
Right.

[after a pause]
I said lift.
[the image pulls back to show Max and Jack lifting Howard Gross' body off his desk]
Uh... right.
Howard Gross here is one of the best PR men we have in the business. Been doing a hell of a job for us for a lot of years. A real pressure player.
[looks at the dead Gross' face under his jacket]
Geez... son-of-a-bitch! He looks pretty bad!
He's dead, sir!
It's all right. You can call me Max.
He's dead, Max!
Mr. Helmes wants Senator Issel's full cooperation when we make our Latin American move. What did you get on him?

[as he hands Dantley papers]
Yes, sir. He's Washington's strongest supporter of big business. That's his voting record. We've contributed over $150,000 to his last campaign and laundered it through our Mexican banks. These are the canceled checks. His wife is a heavy boozer. Those are copies of her liquor store bills. Here are also copies of her police arrest records from various DUI's and drunk and disorderly charges... all dropped due to Issel's "contributions" to the police. Here are copies of Issel's police complaints from domestic abuse charges. He's also having an affair with a DC hooker named Kitten Davis. These are the Polaroids. He's been bribed by every major oil company in the world. These are the telephone transcripts and of couse the standard mens room shots.
Fine.
And his only child and son's college graduation is this morning.
Perfect.

Anyway, I have over 25,000 signatures on that petition. That's the population of Allenville. If your company closes the Allenville plant, those people will lose their jobs and their homes, all because your company can get a little more profit by moving the plant to some poor country where the labor is 10 cents an hour and you guys own the government.
Gosh, you're pretty. Would you like to sit down?
No, thank you. If INC pulls out, this town dies Mr. Issel!
Hey, don't yell at me. I just started working here this morning. Would you like a Diet Coke?
No, thank you. Now if INC would let these workers buy the plant and run it themselves, they could save this town.
That sounds very sensible. Hey, listen, I got to tell you something.
Yes?
You are the most intresting and attractive woman that I've ever met on this job so far.
That's typical. They always dump on us some dumb little guy who just wants to make small talk.
Hey, wait a minute. This little guy is going some place, fella.
And where's that... fella?
30. We can talk about this Allenville thing.
No, thank you. This photocopy of your petition is for your boss.
How about lunch on Thursday? If not, would you like to have dinner with me tonight or tomorrow night?

When I said "write up a report", I wanted you to go out there in the field and listen to what those Allenville protestors had to say! Not make some lunatic suggestion... using my computer key! That could destroy everything that I've worked for to get ahead in this company and take me right back to the steno pool.
I enjoyed your company's little fashion show, senor. Now, business, huh?
[Sepulveda opens up the briefcase Jack gives him and sees a large amount of cash inside]
Very nice, huh? Just like a big drug deal, huh?
[Sepulveda laughs and Jack laughs with him]
Drug deal?
[Jack stops laughing]
I was joking, senor! It was a joke, huh? I never delt dope in my life! That freighter off Miami, it was in my cousin's name. I knew nothing.
I didn't say...

You Americans think you just buy us like that? Giving me this money so I can overthrow President Sanchez for the top spot in San Marcos, huh? You and your self-righteous democracy. You have democracy, my little friend, because you are rich. You can afford both the Mercedes and the free press. We in San Marcos are poor. We can afford only one of them. The Mercedes!
No one trusts me, Mike.
Oh, Al, trust me, they trust you.
I'm too honest for them.
You're not that honest.
Everyone thinks I'm an asshole!
No, not everyone!
Name one person who hasn't called me an asshole. Just one.
Steadman.
Frank Steadman? That asshole? Name someone with clout!
Al, pull yourself together!
Mike, don't shit me. Don't shit a dead man. You're looking at a insect husk, a wacked up, burned out body shell. A dead person!
Al, it's only Monday. You're talking like it's already Friday!

[on the phone to his wife]
Honey, what do you want me to say? I can't talk to you right now! I got 35 guys on hold! I got too many guys on hold! I can't talk to you! Look... what do you want me to say? Your father is dead! There's no point in him being in semi-private! He could be in Yankee Stadium! He doesn't have to be in semi-private! The man is dead! Of course the company has a burial policy, but that doesn't mean that I get covered for it! I got 35 lines here on hold! Hang up for one second!
[flips a switch on the phone]
It wasn't my fault! I'll call you back!
[flips another switch]
It wasn't my fault! I'll call you back!
[as he flips more switches]
It wasn't my fault! It wasn't my fault! It wasn't my fault! It wasn't my fault...

Look at your commitment. I went through college and business school with someone else's notes and a Xerox machine. I xeroxed and cheated my way through life, Rabinovich. "Do the minimum, keep your old man off your back, take the glorious path of least resistance." That's me.
Sounds all right if you can pull it off.
It scares the shit out of me to think that I'm going to be an executive here at 50.
It scares the shit out of me to think I won't be an executive here at 50.
[an angry Jack, realizing that Hudson had Ravinovich fired by framing him, walks into his office as Hudson is yelling at his secretary]
Where's my coffee? Coffee! Now, now, now! Move your goddamned ass!

[takes the coffee pitcher away from the secretary]
Allow me.
[Jack walks up and dumps the coffee all over Hudson's desk and his papers]
Your coffee, sir! Courtesy of Rabinovich. And this is from me!
[Jack overturns Hudson's desk and walks out of the office]

[to Hudson's secretary]
He'll need some cream and sugar.

God, I love this company. I love the action. I love how it test you ever minute of every day. Let your guard down for one second, and the entire system will run over your like a Mac truck. It's merciless.
[as Dantley is talking we cut to Steadman throwing a chair out of his office window]

But when you're up there in that cab, gripping that wheel, pedal to the metal, foot to the floor, flat out screaming down the highway, wind at your heels, the entire power of a multinational corporation pounding on the hood. Ha! Nothing like it. Nothing in the world.

[there is a WHOOSH as a body falls past the window and lands in the plaza fountain far below. Jack, Nixon, and Max run forward and look out the window with Dantley who continues to talk in a casual tone]
Uh... Bob? What was Frank Steadman wearing this morning?

[also talking casual]
An old blue suit, sir.
That's what I thought. Steadman.
[shrugs]
Oh, well.
My God!
The exhilaration of power, that what we're all here for, Jack. But you got to have what it takes. Am I right, Nixon?
Absolutely, sir. You're always right. Steadman's dead.
Looks like it. Anyway, the company is a world onto itself. Company givith, company taketh away. The strong survive, the weak fall. Jack?

[turns back towards Dantley]
Yes?
We won't be easy on you, but I promise you this... be a better man for it.
